PEROT and M. GUISNET URA CNRS 350, Catalyse en Chimie Organique, Universite de Poitiers, 40 avenue du Recteur Pineau, 86022 Poitiers Cedex (France) Summary Like conventional solid catalysts, zeolites offer numerous advantages over liquid catalysts: less or no corrosion, no waste or disposal problems, high thermostability, easy set up of continuous processes, etc. Zeolites also have definite advantages and some disadvantages over conventional solid catalysts in a certain number of applications. Both are discussed in terms of the adjustment of the acidity and basicity, structural effects, concentration and adsorption effects, coke formation and deactivation. Actually, the main advantages of zeolites over conventional catalysts are due to the great acid strength they can have and to their great adaptability to practically all types of catalysis. Numerous potential applica- tions of zeolites have been found in the synthesis of chemicals. The main limitations are (i) the great sensitivity of zeolites to deactivation by irreversible adsorption or steric blockage of heavy secondary products and (ii) the impossibility of using their microporosity for the synthesis of bulky molecules. Because of the greater polarity of functional compounds, it is more difficult to exploit the shape selectivity of zeolites for their reactions than in the case of hydrocarbons. P. at the Indo-French Symposium on Catalysis, Pune, Dec. 1989. 0304-5102/90/$3.50 Elaevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 174 Moreover these solids possess very great adaptability, which certainly constitutes one of their main advantages over conventional catalysts. In the past, zeolites were mainly used in hydrocarbon transformations in processes occurring through acid catalysis (e^. cracking). Indeed, the great density and strength of their Bronsted sites make them very active for difficult reactions. These characteristics also make them potentially interest- ing for certain reactions of functional compounds which at present are carried out with very strong acid solutions. However most of the transforma- tions of functional compounds require for their catalysis sites with moderate acid strength, acid sites plus basic sites (biftmctional acid base catalysis) or even basic sites alone. Zeolites are also potential catalysts for all these reactions since their acid-base properties can be tailored during their synthesis or by a large variety of post-synthesis treatments: partial or total exchange by mono- or plurivalent cations, impregnation by various com- pounds, dealumination [1 4] etc. Zeolites can also be employed as carriers of redox components in well-dispersed form [5]. The properties of these components superimpose upon the intrinsic characteristics of the zeolites, which are then active for reactions ofoxidoreduction or for reactions implying both acid base and redox sites (polyfunctional catalysis). Another of their potential advantages over amorphous solids results from their well-defined pore structure, with pores of about the size of organic molecules. Actually their selectivity depends not only on the intrinsic properties of the catalytic sites but also on the pore structure [6 11]. Therefore a high selectivity can be obtained not only by adjustment of the properties of the active sites but also by judicious choice and adjustment of the zeolite pore structure. In particular, the chemical vapor deposition of various compounds on the outer surface of the crystallites (or their grafting) allows precise control of the size of the zeolite pore apertures [12]. This possibility of adjusting the properties of the active sites and the pore structure makes the zeolites interesting not only industrially for fine chemical reactions but also for the comprehension of the mechanisms of these reactions. However, zeolites have some inconveniences. Thus, while due to the pore structure the selectivity can be very high, the size of the synthesized molecule is obviously limited by the size of the pore apertures and of the cavities (or of the channel intersections). Another problem is the sensitivity of zeolites to the deactivation by coke: relatively small amounts of coke can block access of the reactant to the active sites [13]. In spite of these disadvantages, zeolites seem to be the best catalysts for all types of transformations of functional compounds. However we shall see that zeolites present still other disadvantages. This paper is not intended to be an exhaustive survey of the applic- ability of zeolites to organic chemistry. Excellent reviews on the subject have already been published [14-26]. We shall simply present selected examples of reactions in order to illustrate some of the advantages and disadvantages of zeolites with respect to conventional liquid or solid catalysts. 175 Adjustment of acidity and basicity of zeolites Acidity All the characteristics of zeolite acidity: distribution in nature (Lewis and Bronsted sites), strength, density of the acid sites, can be modified by a large number of treatments. However it is generally impossible to modify these characteristics independently. For example the treatment at high temperature of protonic zeolites causes the transformation of Bronsted sites into Lewis sites. Yet the protonic sites of the dehydroxylated zeolites are stronger than those of the starting zeolites [27]. On the other hand, dealumination decreases the acid site density but can increase the acid strength [3, 28] and can modify the porosity [3]. Acid strength The alkylation of aromatics bearing electron-withdrawing groups requires very strong acid sites. For instance, the gas phase alkylation of chlorobenzene with methanol on H-mordenite [29] is about 50 times slower than that of toluene. This reaction occurs very slowly on zeolites such as USHY or REY, which have not very strong acid sites, but occurs rapidly on acid zeolites such as HZSM5 and H-mordenite, which have stronger acid sites. Aromatic nitration and hydroxylation are well known for requiring very strong acid media for the generation of the electrophile. Nitration of aromatics is carried out industrially in a liquid phase process by using a mixture of nitric acid and concentrated sulfuric acid. This process creates serious problems of corrosion and of pollution. Aromatic nitration can also be carried out with nitrogen dioxide in a strongly acid medium such as trifluoroacetic acid. Ono and coworkers [30] have shown that the vapour phase nitration of benzene proceeds over sulfonated polyphenylsiloxane catalysts with a good nitrobenzene yield. A patent from Monsanto [31] describes the vapour-phase nitration of aromatic compounds on zeolite catalysts. Obviously this vapour phase nitration does not have the disadvan- tages of the liquid phase process. Site density The density of the acid sites has a significant effect on the stability of zeolite catalysts (see below). It has also a pronounced effect on their selectivity in consecutive reactions, such as the hydrocracking of n-paramns [34]: while on catalysts having a low acid site density the n-alkane transformation actually occurs through a step-by-step process, the apparent reaction scheme is parallel on catalysts with a high density of acid sites [34]. This probably occurs (but has not yet been shown) for consecutive reactions of functional compounds such as the electrophilic substitutions of aromatics. The acid site density can also affect the selectivity of transformations occurring through parallel reactions. Thus the higher the Si/Al ratio of a Y zeolite (hence the lower the acid site density), the lower the disproportionation/isomerization rate ratio in the transformation of xylenes [35]. To explain this observation, it was proposed that the bimoleeular reaction of disproportionation demanded adjacent catalytic sites while the isomerization (monomolecular) required only one acid site. In the alkylation of phenol with methanol over HY zeolites there is also a change in selectivity with the acid site density. The lower the density, the higher the o/p-cresol selectivity. It was suggested that para-substitution was only possible if there was more than one acid site per supercage [36]. Structural effects accessible surface area As mentioned in the introduction, one of the characteristics of zeolites is that the dimensions of their pores (apertures and cavities) are of the same order of magnitude as those of organic molecules of relatively small size. This can be considered a big advantage of zeolites over amorphous materials, as it gives rise to their ability to discriminate among molecules, intermediates or transition states according to their size and shape. This property was first depicted by Weisz and Frilette in 1960 and was designated by reactant, product and transition state shape selectivity [6]. Since then numerous applications have been found in the field of hydrocarbon chemistry, and shape selectivity has been the subject of numerous review articles [7-11]. However the fact that zeolite pores have relatively small apertures has also a few disadvantages, especially in the field of functional compounds. One is that bulky molecules will only be able to react on the external surface of the catalyst particles. Although this can sometimes represent a significant part of the total surface area [56], this can be considered as a small fraction of the potential active surface area. The other drawback is that bulky molecules of products may be trapped inside the cavities and lead to deactivation of the catalyst. Selectivity effects in the case of parallel reactions A typical example is the regioselectivity (i.e. para-selectivity) in the electrophilic substitution of aromatics. This selectivity is due to the fact that the less bulky para-isomer diffuses faster than the ortho. Thus with 10-membered ring zeolites such as pentasil zeolites, it is possible to obtain a very high selectivity in para-xylene by alkylation of toluene with methanol [57]. As we will see, numerous examples of shape selectivity also exist in the field of molecules containing heteroatoms, although the product distribution can be modified by factors other than purely steric. In a recent review article Parton et al. [25] discuss the selectivities obtained m the alkylation of phenol by methanol. In addition to the work of Namba et al. [32] mentioned above, numerous results in the literature are actually in agreement with the hypothesis that anisole formation would require weak acid sites [58 60]. Faujasites, which are thought to have weaker acid sites than pentasil zeolites, have generally a higher selectivity for anisole [61 63]. Moreover HNaZSMO also has a higher selectivity than HZSM5 [64, 65]. However, several authors report high selectivities in anisole [36, 58, 66] on protonic pentasil zeolites. In certain cases pentasil zeolites (HZSM5, HZSM11) are even more selective in anisole than Y zeolites [36, 66]. Since the former are known to exhibit stronger acidity than the latter, this can only be attributed to shape selectivity. The second point concerning the alkylation of phenol by methanol is that on zeolites the selectivity in para-cresol is not very high, although it is generally higher than on amorphous and especially on basic materials. In this latter case the explanation is that phenol can be vertically adsorbed on the surface, thus favouring C-alkylation in the ortho position [67]. The role of the solid can then be to concentrate the substrate, to sterically orient the reaction or to stabilize the products so that they cannot react further. Thus Bram and Loupy have reported that a large variety of reactions takes place in the presence of solids such as silica [90] or alumina [89] instead of liquid solvents. Interesting effects were observed concerning reaction yields as well as selectivity. Similar effects were obtained in the presence of zeolites. Risbood and Ruthven [92] reported that the reduction of aldehydes in the presence of ketones using LiBH4 deposited on A and X zeolites was highly selective, whereas a very poor selectivity was obtained when the reaction was carried out in homoge- neous solutions. They found that only a small amount of LiBH4 was adsorbed on the zeolite; moreover they obtained almost the same selectivity with X zeolites in which both the ketone and the aldehyde can penetrate and with A zeolites in which only the aldehyde can penetrate. Therefore they conclude that the selectivity of the reducing agent does not arise from a molecular sieve effect but rather from a phenomenon occurring on the external surface of the crystals. In certain reactions involving water, the hydrophilic or hydrophobic character of the zeolite can affect its activity. Thus in carboxylic acid esterification [93] or in ethylenic hydrocarbon hydration [94], it has been shown that the most hydrophobic zeolites were the most active. However, it is very difficult to distinguish between the effects resulting from hydrophili- city or hydrophobicity and the effects resulting from acidity, because both are linked [94]. Concentration effect The pore size of zeolites being comparable to the size of organic molecules, these molecules are strongly adsorbed and their effective con- centration in the vicinity of the internal acid sites is greater than their concentration in the gas phase. Thus at 200 C, the concentration of n-heptane in NaX pores is about 250 times greater than the gas concentra- tion [1]. This concentration effect influences the activity, the selectivity and the kinetics of the reactions. It is largely responsible for the higher activity of the acid sites of zeolites compared to conventional catalysts such as silica-alumina [95,96]. The greater hydrogen transfer rate/chain-scission rate ratio found in F.C.C, with zeolite catalysts compared to silica-alumina is mainly due to this concentration effect. Indeed a higher concentration would increase the rate of the bimolecular hydrogen transfer reactions more than the rate of the monomolecular cracking reactions [95, 96]. Obviously, a higher activity of zeolites compared to conventional catalysts and a higher selectivity for bimolecular reactions should also be found in the transformation of functional compounds. These particularities 188 are however more difficult to demonstrate in this case, because other parameters may interfere. In particular, most of the transformations of functional compounds require acid base sites, whose intrinsic properties are less well-defined than those of acid sites and depend more on the catalyst considered. The kinetics of the reactions catalyzed by zeolites is also influenced by this concentration effect. This was shown in the case of the hydrocracking of paraffins on Pt zeolites [97-100]. This reaction occurs through a bifunctional mechanism, the limiting step being the transformation of the carbenium ion intermediates. With this mechanism the reaction orders with respect to hydrogen and to the alkane are expected to be equal to -1 and 1 respectively. If the order with respect to hydrogen is indeed equal to 1, the order with respect to the alkane is below 1 even at low alkane pressures. Obviously, the smaller the size of the pores the lower the pressure above which the order will be below 1. Thus for n-heptane hydrocracking this pressure is equal to about 50 kPa on Pt-HY and to 5 kPa on Pt-HZSM5 [100]. The change in the activity as a function of the alkane pressure is in agreement with the change expected from the bifunctional mechanism, provided the concentration of the alkane in the vicinity of the active sites is taken to be the concentration of physisorbed alkane calculated on the basis of the Langmuir Hinshelwood model [97 100]. As the functional compounds have a high polarity, they adsorb certainly more strongly than the hydrocarbons. Therefore, their concentration in the zeolite micropores must be much higher than in the gas phase and the reaction orders very low. This is actually the case for the alkylation of phenol with methanol over HY zeolites [101]. In this reaction, the mechanism is suggested to be a Rideal-type mechanism in which phenol in the gas phase is expected to react with adsorbed methanol. This would lead to a first-order reaction with respect to phenol. However, a zero order with respect to phenol is observed even at very low pressures (2 10 kPa). For many reactions of functional compounds, there is no positive effect of the pressure on the rate and hence no reason to operate at high pressure. Coke formation and deactivation As was the case for hydrocarbon transformations, the deposit inside the pores and/or on the outer surface of secondary heavy reaction products ('coke') is the main cause of the deactivation of zeolites during the transformation of functional compounds [13, 29, 36, 102-104]. It is thus not surprising that nearly half of the patents in the field of synthesis of specialty chemicals on zeolites concern ZSM5, known for its low coking activity. The effect of the zeolite characteristics (acidity, porosity, etc.) and the operating conditions (temperature, nature and pressure of reactants, etc.) on the coking and deactivation rates is now well-known for the transformation of hydrocarbons. In contrast, very few studies are available concerning the transformation of functional compounds. We shall show here from these 189 preliminary studies that the main conclusions drawn in the case of hydro- carbon transformations seem to apply to the reactions of functional compounds. Coke composition, location, mode of formation The compounds responsible for zeolite deactivation during hydrocarbon transformation are located not only on the outer surface but also in the micropores, and consequently are not always polyaromatic. Therefore we have decided to define 'coke' as the heavy secondary products (polyaromatic or non-polyaromatic) of a reaction retained inside and/or on the zeolite [13]. A technique has been developed for characterizing zeolite coke [105], which consists of treating the coked samples with a solution of hydrofluoric add in order to dissolve the zeolite and to liberate the internal coke. The components of coke, soluble in CHaClg, are analyzed by GC, IR, HNMR, MS, etc. while the non-soluble part is characterized by electron microscopy and electron energy loss spectroscopy. A great deal of information on the coking phenomena has been obtained from the composition of coke formed during hydrocarbon transformation on zeolites [13]: the size of the coke molecules and their aromaticity increases with time on stream. Generally coke begins to form inside the cavities (or at the channel intersections). External coke appears at high time on stream by growth of the molecules of internal coke. The nature and the distribution of the coke components depend on the pore structure. At high reaction temperature their molecular size is intermediate between the size of the apertures and that of the cavities (or of the channel intersections); the retention of coke molecules is caused by steric blockage. At low reaction temperature their size is often smaller than the size of the apertures and their retention is due to their low volatility. The formation of coke molecules occurs through numerous successive bimolecular steps. The characterization, by the same technique, of the coke formed during phenol alkylation with methanol on USHY at 200 C led to similar conclu- sions [102]. All the coke components are soluble in methylene chloride. They have 1 to 3 aromatic rings bearing hydroxy or methoxy groups (Table 6). These compounds are located in the zeolite micropores. Indeed the kinetic diameter of the main components is smaller than the pore aperture of the zeolite. Furthermore their boiling points can be estimated between 210 C and 460 C. Therefore at least the more volatile compounds could be eliminated under the operating conditions if they were located on the outer surface. At the low temperature chosen for reaction, their retention in the zeolite pores can be attributed to their low volatility and to a condensation effect. Operating at a higher reaction temperature decreased the retention of these compounds. Unfortunately methanol was then transformed into olefins which led to the formation of polyaromatic coke [106]. Coking and deactivation rates Thanks to the use of series of zeolites with different Si/Al ratios obtained by synthesis (e.g. MFI) or by dealumination (e.g. FAU), the very significant role the acid site density plays in the rato of coking during hydrocarbon transformations is now well demonstrated [13]: the higher the Si/Al ratio (hence the lower the acid site density), the slower the coking and therefore the deactivation of the zeolite. This was also found during various transformations of functional compounds: alkylation of chlorobenzenes [29] or of phenol [36], Beckmann rearrangement [86], condensation of for- maldehyde with benzene [103], conversion ofcarboxylic acids [108] etc. The strength of the acid sites, the pore structure, the operating conditions (nature of the reactant and of the products, temperature, etc.) also play significant roles in the coking and deactivation phenomena. Thus for the Beckmann rearrangement [24, 86], the acid strength plays a negative role. Only rather weak acidity is required to obtain a long catalyst lifetime (and also a high selectivity at high conversion). Furthermore it is obvious [13] that since coking occurs mainly in the pores of zeolites, the coking rate is all the greater when: (i) the space available for its formation (in the cavities or at the channel intersections) is greater. (ii) the coke precursors diffuse more slowly into the gas phase. 191 It is probably because of this latter point that the more basic an aromatic reactant the greater the coke production [109]. Indeed the contact time between the acid zeolite and the reactant increases with the basicity, therefore increasing the possibility of secondary reactions leading to coke. For the same reason the size of the reactant molecule also plays a significant role. It is well demonstrated in the case of hydrocarbon transformations that the sensitivity of zeolites to deactivation by coke depends a great deal on their pore structure [13]. Thus coke has a more pronounced deactivating effect on zeolites such as mordenite in which the organic molecules can diffuse only in one direction than on tridimensional zeolites such as Y or ZSM5 zeolites. Indeed a single coke deposit in a large channel of the mordenite is sufficient to block the access of the reactant to the totality of the acid sites of this channel, while a coke deposit in a large cavity of Y zeolite or at a channel intersection of HZSM5 only blocks the access to the sites of this large cavity or of this channel intersection. However erionite, which has a tridimensional network, deactivates very rapidly; this can be attributed to the presence of large cavities with small apertures acting like traps for numerous reaction products. It must be noted that because of the creation of mesopores, the dealumination by steaming of monodimensional zeolites, which decreases the coking rate, can also decrease the coke toxicity [110]. The coke formed from functional compounds being mainly located in the pores of the zeolite, blockage of the access of the reactant molecules to the active sites is the main cause of deactivation and the deactivating effect of coke will depend in the same way on the pore structure. How to limit the deactivation of zeolites There are great similitudes in the modes of coking and deactivation during the reactions of hydrocarbons and of functional compounds on zeolites. Therefore the possibilities for limiting the deactivation of zeolites are identical. First, it is necessary to adjust the acidobasicity and the pore structure to the reaction. In particular, in order to avoid the successive secondary reactions leading to coke, the lowest possible site density neces- sary to obtain the desired activity will be chosen. Zeolites having monodi- mensional frameworks or large cavities with small apertures which are very sensitive to deactivation [13] will be avoided. Steric constraints near the active sites caused by the pore structure (as such or modified, for instance by deposits) can inhibit the formation of heavy secondary products. Coke formation and deactivation of zeolites during hydrocarbon transformations can be limited by the addition of a hydrogenating agent. Under hydrogen such an agent, even if present in low amounts, allows the hydrogenation of coke precursors with consequently a sharp decrease in the coking and deactivation rates. This is particularly evident when there is a change from an acid to a bifunctional mechanism (e.g. cracking on acid zeolites to hydrocracking on Pt acid zeolites). But it can also be the case for the typical reactions of acid catalysis such as toluene disproportionation [111]. This 192 scavenger effect of hydrogen could, without doubt, also be of interest in the synthesis of certain functional compounds. It must be noted that the amount of hydrogenating agent can be very small, which eliminates the risk of secondary reactions. Moreover, in certain cases acid zeolites without any hydrogenating additive can activate hydrogen, particularly if it is used under pressure [11, 112]. Very strong add sites could be responsible for this activation of hydrogen, unless this effect is caused simply by hydrogenating impurities in the zeolite. Hydrogen is not the only agent capable of limiting the formation of coke; other compounds, either reductors or oxidants (for instance oxygen), can play the same role. As for hydrocarbon transformations, operating conditions should be chosen so as to limit: (i) the formation of compounds leading very rapidly to coke. For instance cumene or ethylbenzene disproportionation can be carried out practically without deactivation at temperatures below 250 C [113, 114] because there is no production of olefins (no dealkylation) well-known as coke precursors; (ii) the secondary successive reactions generally involved in the forma- tion of the compounds responsible for deactivation (low contact time, recycling, etc.); (iii) the deposit of heavy secondary reaction products inside the pores or on the outer surface (reactions in liquid phase with solvents rather than in gas phase, etc.). Conclusion Zeolites have definite advantages over conventional catalysts in certain applications. These advantages are due essentially on one hand to their acid strength and on the other to their adaptability to practically all the types of catalysis: acid, acid-base, base, oxidation, reduction, polyfunctional. Yet they have several definite disadvantages which are still difficult to remedy in spite of the great progress made in the synthesis of new zeolite materials (e.g. VPI 5) and m the modification of existing materials. The first is the deaetivation by irreversible adsorption of heavy secondary products. The second is the impossibility of using the porosity for the synthesis or the transformation of bulky molecules. Zeolites can therefore be used essentially in the synthesis of specialty chemicals rather than fine chemicals. The position is less clear as far as shape selectivity is concerned, which in the case of hydrocarbons is admitted to be one of the main advantages of zeolites on amorphous oxides. The difficulty results from the fact that the more one tries to exploit the shape selectivity of zeolites, the closer the size of the pores must be to that of the molecules and hence the more the phenomenon of condensation in the pores becomes significant. Guisnet URA CNRS 350, Catalyse en Chimie Organique, UniversitÃ© de Poitiers, 40 avenue du Recteur Pineau, 86022 Poitiers CÃ©dexFrance Like conventional solid catalysts, zeolites offer numerous advantages over liquid catalysts: less or no corrosion, no waste or disposal problems, high thermostability, easy set up of continuous processes, etc. Zeolites also have definite advantages and some disadvantages over conventional solid catalysts in a certain number of applications. Both are discussed in terms of the adjustment of the acidity and basicity, structural effects, concentration and adsorption effects, coke formation and deactivation. Actually, the main advantages of zeolites over conventional catalysts are due to the great acid strength they can have and to their great adaptability to practically all types of catalysis. Numerous potential applications of zeolites have been found in the synthesis of chemicals. The main limitations are (i) the great sensitivity of zeolites to deactivation by irreversible adsorption or steric blockage of heavy secondary products and (ii) the impossibility of using their microporosity for the synthesis of bulky molecules. coredata.dc:description: Like conventional solid catalysts, zeolites offer numerous advantages over liquid catalysts: less or no corrosion, no waste or disposal problems, high thermostability, easy set up of continuous processes, etc. Zeolites also have definite advantages and some disadvantages over conventional solid catalysts in a certain number of applications. Both are discussed in terms of the adjustment of the acidity and basicity, structural effects, concentration and adsorption effects, coke formation and deactivation. Actually, the main advantages of zeolites over conventional catalysts are due to the great acid strength they can have and to their great adaptability to practically all types of catalysis. Numerous potential applications of zeolites have been found in the synthesis of chemicals. The main limitations are (i) the great sensitivity of zeolites to deactivation by irreversible adsorption or steric blockage of heavy secondary products and (ii) the impossibility of using their microporosity for the synthesis of bulky molecules. Because of the greater polarity of functional compounds, it is more difficult to exploit the shape selectivity of zeolites for their reactions than in the case of hydrocarbons.
